    @agahkarakuzu, @mathieuboudreau
    https://github.com/neuropoly/qMRLab


The main goal is to provide an intuitive tool for data fitting, plotting, simulation and protocol optimization for a myriad of different quantitative models. This project will involve bridging the gab between quantitative MRI and pre-processing tools by introducing SPM into the qMRLab data processing workflow.

title: NIDM-Results in Datalad

labels.name: CHECK_LABEL
labels.description: Labels needs to be checked by a human

body:
Added as an issue for book keeping

Source: https://brainhackmtl.github.io/informatics2018/projects.html

Leaders:

    Camille Maumet, Yaroslav Halchenko
    @cmaumet, @yarikoptic
    http://www.datalad.org/, [http://nidm.nidash.org/specs/](http://nidm.nidash.org/specs/nidm-results.html)


NIDM-Results is a standardised representation for fMRI Results. Datalad provides version-control for datasets and has built-in support for metadata extraction and search. This project will start from reviewing basics of Datalad, and eventually look at NIDM-Results metadata available on NeuroVault in Datalad.

A light-weight RESTful API and web portal for querying arbitrary (described) local and remote datasets. This project will involve creating JSON schemas describing various data formats for Apine, and using them to explore datasets.

title: Stan

labels.name: CHECK_LABEL
labels.description: Labels needs to be checked by a human

body:
Added as an issue for book keeping

Source: https://brainhackfinland.github.io/2018/#hackathon-projects

To run Stan you need to install R (see above) with packages [rstan](https://cran.r-project.org/package=rstan) and [rstanarm](https://cran.r-project.org/package=rstanarm). The former has the functions that are needed to run arbitrary Stan programs, whereas the latter has precompiled Stan codes for some of the most common regression models (like linear regression, logistic regression etc.) with easy-to-use interface.

title: SideR

labels.name: CHECK_LABEL
labels.description: Labels needs to be checked by a human

body:
Added as an issue for book keeping

Source: https://brainhackfinland.github.io/2018/#hackathon-projects

SideR can be found here: http://www.iki.fi/kaip/sider.html. Before coming to the hackathon, you need to have the following software installed before running sideR:
* R 3.4.0 or higher with the following packages which can be installed from CRAN (see https://www.r-bloggers.com/installing-r-packages/ for instructions): shiny, fastICA.
* A modern web browser such as Google Chrome.

We have tested sideR with a unix system (Mac OS X) but it should work in any system that has R with the above mentioned packages installed.

NB: R 3.4.0 includes somes substantial speedups to matrix computations which may affect the performance of the sideR. If you have an older version of R installed we therefore strongly recommended you to update to R 3.4.0 or newer!

An alternative to sideR is
tileR which can be found here https://github.com/aheneliu/tiler along with installation instructions.

title: Polygenic Cell-type enrichment tester

labels.name: CHECK_LABEL
labels.description: Labels needs to be checked by a human

body:
Added as an issue for book keeping

Source: https://github.com/CAMH-SCWG/to-brainhack-2018/wiki

Team Members: Leon French, Derek Howard

The goal of this project is to build a tool that will test if a given set of genes are specifically expressed in a transcriptomically defined mouse nervous system cell-type. This will leverage new single cell data from the Linnarson lab (Zeisel et al., 2018, https://www.biorxiv.org/content/early/2018/04/06/294918). We will build this in R as a Shiny web app.

title: NeurosynthRecommendR: A semantic analysis and recommendation engine for fMRI literature based on Neurosynth.

labels.name: CHECK_LABEL
labels.description: Labels needs to be checked by a human

body:
Added as an issue for book keeping

Source: https://github.com/CAMH-SCWG/to-brainhack-2018/wiki

Team Members: [Fahd Alhazmi](http://github.com/fahd09), Derek Beaton, [Perhaps you?!]

We analyzed the [multivariate semantic structure of abstracts in Neurosynth](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/hbm.24038) and found that there are six primary domains of the functional neuroimaging literature, each with their own preferred reported brain regions. All of the code is available [here](https://github.com/fahd09/neurosynth_semantic_map). One of the features we developed was a [recommendation engine](https://neurosanity.shinyapps.io/NeurosynthRecommendR/), that allows for the exploration of the fMRI literature. We are hoping to extend this work in a variety of ways:

* Broader search to incorporate more of the neuroscience and psychology literature

* Allow for more advanced semantic analyses through the use of full terms and n-grams

* Create a prediction module which suggests where a new paper was submitted to or should be submitted

* Update and add features to the recommendation interface (e.g., tabular output instead of a download)

title: MARINeR: Multivariate analysis and resampling inference for neuroimaging in R.

labels.name: CHECK_LABEL
labels.description: Labels needs to be checked by a human

body:
Added as an issue for book keeping

Source: https://github.com/CAMH-SCWG/to-brainhack-2018/wiki

Team Members: Jenny Rieck, Derek Beaton, [Perhaps you?!]

Description: Our goal with MARINeR is to have a comprehensive neuroimaging multivariate analysis package in R. Currently we have started development of some of the core parts of the package: imaging file I/O, analysis engine (generalized singular value decomposition), specific analyses (e.g., PCA), and some minimal aspects of preprocessing (e.g., detrending). For BrainHack Global TO 2018 we have the following goals:

1. Finish file I/O

2. A completed version of principal components analysis

3. A completed version of two types of partial least squares (mean-centered/discriminant, and standard). 

All code is in R or dependent on R packages that interface with other languages (e.g., Rcpp, reticulate). Package development and progress can be seen here: https://github.com/derekbeaton/MARINeR

If you're interested in helping or learning more about R, neuroimaging, and multivariate analyses just find us at BrainHack or let us know on the following brainhack Slack channels: #brainhack-toronto, #bhg-rstats, #mariner

title: Cog psych experiments with Muse EEG for NeuroBRITE

labels.name: CHECK_LABEL
labels.description: Labels needs to be checked by a human

body:
Added as an issue for book keeping

Source: https://github.com/CAMH-SCWG/to-brainhack-2018/wiki

Team Members: John Griffiths, Derek Beaton, Amanda Easson  [please add your name if you're interested!]

NeuroBRITE is an outreach program run by the Rotman Research Institute at Baycrest, with the aim of introducing final year high school students to cognitive neuroscience and scientific computing. Students will design, conduct, and analyze EEG-based psychological experiments on the theme of cognitive ageing.

The aim of this brainhack project is to develop two parts of the NeuroBRITE curriculum:

1.  Implementation + testing of several cog psych experimental paradigms in the areas of memory, executive function, and perception for use with muse EEG. 

2. Development of didactic introductory+intermediate material for students and teachers. 

For 1), stimulus presentation and experiment control will be psychopy-based, building off the excellent examples in [muse-lsl](https://github.com/alexandrebarachant/muse-lsl) python library. Off-line data analyses shall be implemented using a combination of Python and R tools.

title: Converting Partial Least Squares (PLS) Software from Matlab to Python

labels.name: CHECK_LABEL
labels.description: Labels needs to be checked by a human

body:
Added as an issue for book keeping

Source: https://github.com/CAMH-SCWG/to-brainhack-2018/wiki

Team Members: Amanda Easson, John Griffiths [please add your name if you're interested!]

Description: The partial least squares (PLS) software that was developed by Dr. Randy McIntosh and colleagues at the Rotman Research Institute at Baycrest is currently implemented in Matlab. The aim of this project is to convert the PLS functions to Python. The core PLS functions have already been converted to Python; thus, during the Toronto Brainhack, we will work on converting the other functions to Python and writing additional scripts and tutorials to teach the neuroscience community how to use PLS and visualize their results.

title: Quasi Periodic Pattern extraction code in Python.

labels.name: CHECK_LABEL
labels.description: Labels needs to be checked by a human

body:
Added as an issue for book keeping

Source: https://github.com/CAMH-SCWG/to-brainhack-2018/wiki
 
Team Members: Sadia Shakil [please add your name if you're interested!]

Description: Quasi periodic patterns (QPPs) were discovered by Dr. Shella keilholz group and are studied to understand the neural basis of functional connectivity in intrinsic brain functionality. This project will code its algorithm in Python. The project will also look at the contribution of QPPs by finding the functional connectivity before and after the regression of these patterns. Mainly, QPP code already available in MATLAB by Dr. Keilhoz’s group will be converted to Python.

title: Thalamocortical neural field models of EEG data in tensorflow

labels.name: CHECK_LABEL
labels.description: Labels needs to be checked by a human

body:
Added as an issue for book keeping

Source: https://github.com/CAMH-SCWG/to-brainhack-2018/wiki

Team Members:  John Griffiths, Rabiya Noori, Daniel Park, Jeremie Lefebvre, Ayda Ghahremani [please add your name if you're interested!]

The aim of this project is to implement a relatively simple physiological model of macro-scale neural dynamics generating EEG signals in tensorflow. 

*Objectives:*

- Implement (in python) the robinson thalamocortical neural field model (spectral-domain variant)  
- make jupyter notebook widgets for interactively exploring depandence of model outputs on parameter values  
- Implement model fitting & parameter estimation using `tensorflow` / `scipy.optimize` / `scikit.optimize`  
- Derive mathematically the equivalent analytic spectral form for an alternative model formulation (with wilson-cowan equations) 
 

The github repository for this project is [here](https://github.com/Lefebvrelab/SpectralNeuralModels). See [here](https://github.com/Lefebvrelab/SpectralNeuralModels/blob/master/scratch/robinson_spectral_model_notes.ipynb) for some initial notes and code sketches.

*We are looking for additional recruits with experience and/or interest in: `python`, `tensorflow`, `neurophysiological modelling`, and `M/EEG data analysis`.*

title: Find The Bug: The Other Human in The Loop

labels.name: CHECK_LABEL
labels.description: Labels needs to be checked by a human

body:
Added as an issue for book keeping

Source: https://brainhack.psychoinformatics.de/projects.html

Leader:
    Daniel Kottke
    daniel.kottke@uni-kassel.de
    [Website](https://www.ies.uni-kassel.de/p/bug-study/)

Recently, we conducted a pilot study with humans to find selection strategies for a machine learning task (active learning). In this project, we develop the concept of an advanced version of the previously used paper card game extending the existing study. Furthermore, we take a look into existing data from the previous study to state interesting research hypotheses.

title: Now You See It, Now You Don't: Virtual Reality and Vision

labels.name: CHECK_LABEL
labels.description: Labels needs to be checked by a human

body:
Added as an issue for book keeping

Source: https://brainhack.psychoinformatics.de/projects.html

Leader:

    Nico Marek
    nico.marek@ovgu.de
    [Pupil Labs](https://pupil-labs.com/vr-ar/)
    [Unity](https://unity3d.com/unity)

Virtual reality enables us not only to create artificial environments, we can also manipulate what — and how — participants are seeing. For this project, we will try to implement artificial limitations to vision (with and without VR-eye-tracking), create basic environments to explore and interact with, and implement basic experimental procedures to collect behavioral data in Unity3D.

title: Seeing is Believing: Connecting VR Environments to EEG Output Interpretation

labels.name: CHECK_LABEL
labels.description: Labels needs to be checked by a human

body:
Added as an issue for book keeping

Source: https://brainhack.psychoinformatics.de/projects.html

Leader:
    Siew-Wan Ohl; JiaHua Xu
    siew-wan.ohl@ovgu.de; jiahua.xu@med.ovgu.de
    [Edu2VR](http://www.edu2vr.com/)
    [OpenBCI](http://openbci.com/)

For this project, we would like to see what EEG signals will be generated when different VR environments or scenarios are presented to the user. It is up to the creativity of the programmer to either generate interesting VR environments or directly import existing 360 degree photos or videos from online databases (e.g. YouTube). We will record EEG signals and attempt to interpret them in accordance to the VR scenarios being watched.

Additive manufacturing provides exciting opportunities in the lab: need a prototype? Just print it! More of these super expensive small parts that evil ACME Corp overcharges you for? 3D-printers for the rescue! In this project we will take a look at the workflow of FDM 3D printing and how you can implement it in your lab.

title: Hear What I Hear: Reconstructing the Music in Our Heads

labels.name: CHECK_LABEL
labels.description: Labels needs to be checked by a human

body:
Added as an issue for book keeping

Source: https://brainhack.psychoinformatics.de/projects.html

Leader:

    Andrew Curran
    andrew.curran@med.ovgu.de
    [Visual Image Reconstruction](http://www.eneuro.org/content/early/2018/01/29/ENEURO.0358-17.2018)

Recently, research groups have shown that it is possible to read images from a person's brain as they are seen using both fMRI and EEG through machine learning strategies. These strategies have however not yet been applied to auditory stimuli. It should theoretically also be possible to record imagined visual or auditory perceptions. This project aims to utilize the same principles to extract simple musical details through EEG, and potentially even imagined music.

title: Brain Network Analysis Pipelines in Neuroimaging Data

labels.name: CHECK_LABEL
labels.description: Labels needs to be checked by a human

Added as an issue for book keeping

Leader:

    jiahua.xu@med.ovgu.de
    [FieldTrip](http://www.fieldtriptoolbox.org/)
    [MNE](https://www.martinos.org/mne/stable/index.html)
    [Brain Connectivity Toolbox](https://sites.google.com/site/bctnet/)

This project will focus on the pipelines of brain network analysis when using EEG data with different kinds of graphics measures, from mathematics to practical. The aim is to help visualize the brain dynamic connectivity changes and understand the network structures of brain activities in a different perspective.

title: Machine Learning with Dask and Neuroimaging Data

labels.name: CHECK_LABEL
labels.description: Labels needs to be checked by a human

body:
Added as an issue for book keeping

Source: https://brainhack.psychoinformatics.de/projects.html

Leader:

    José P. Valdés-Herrera
    jose.valdes@dzne.de
    [Dask](https://dask.pydata.org/)

The aim of this project is to analyse large neuroimaging datasets — that do not fit in memory — even without access to powerful machines or clusters. To achieve this, we can use machine learning libraries (Nilearn, PyMVPA, scikit-learn) together with a library like Dask. During the event, the goal is to integrate these tools, pick a large dataset, and analyse it on "modest" hardware (e.g. a laptop).

title: Containerized Nipype Pipelines on the Cluster
body:
Added as an issue for book keeping

Source: https://brainhack.psychoinformatics.de/projects.html

Leader:

    José P. Valdés-Herrera
    jose.valdes@dzne.de
    [Nipype](http://nipype.readthedocs.io/)
    [Docker](https://www.docker.com/)
    [Singularity](http://singularity.lbl.gov/)

This project proposes taking custom or already available pipelines developed using Nipype, package them in a container using Docker or Singularity, and integrate them with cluster software (SLURM, SGE, Condor). The aim is to automate the process of taking those pipelines to a cluster as much as possible, either by developing scripts or extending Nipype's functionality.

title: Basics of Image Reconstruction: From Raw Data to the Image
body:
Added as an issue for book keeping

Source: https://brainhack.psychoinformatics.de/projects.html

Leader:

    Falk Lüsebrink
    falk.luesebrink@ovgu.de

In this project, a basic reconstruction pipeline is to be developed for Cartesian sampled gradient echo data. This includes reading raw data, k space filtering, data synthesis in case of partial Fourier, coil combination (sum of squares and adaptive combination) and writing of image files. The aim is to reconstruct image with at least the quality of the vendors.

title: BIDS-app-Based Searchlight Analysis Pipeline
body:
Added as an issue for book keeping

Source: https://brainhack.psychoinformatics.de/projects.html

Leader:
    Michael Hanke
    michael.hanke@gmail.com

Links:
    [BIDS-app](http://bids-apps.neuroimaging.io/)
    [PyMVPA](http://www.pymvpa.org/)

Decoding analyses using a traveling "searchlight" are a widely used approach to map the availability of a given signal, and can also be used for a representational similarity analysis (RSA). This project aims to produce a BIDS-app for a PyMVPA-based searchlight analysis for decoding and RSA.

title: Fun side project to explore: How to 3D print our own brain from a T1 MRI image
body:
Added as an issue for book keeping

Source: https://brainhackghent.github.io/#projects

Leader:
Sofie Van Den Bossche

Aim:
We will follow the steps mentioned in this [GitHub code](https://github.com/miykael/3dprintyourbrain) in order to create a 3D model of our own brain. Thereafter we will check the model and explore rescaling options. Alternative guides for 3D printing brains can be examined as well.

When you decide to participate, it’s recommended to already have [Freesurfer](http://freesurfer.net/) and [meshlab](http://www.meshlab.net/) installed on your system, since these are the main software tools used in the above-mentioned GitHub code.

Requirements:
You need to bring a T1 MRI image of your own brain.

title: Pre-processing of (resting state) EEG data of chronic pain patients
body:
Added as an issue for book keeping

Source: https://brainhackghent.github.io/#projects

Leader:
Dorine Lenoir

Aim:
In this project, I would like to learn how pre-processing of EEG data should be performed. Both theoretically as practically, I would like to acquire knowledge on how to obtain optimal data for further analyses. This for both resting state EEG, as for EEG data acquired during electrical stimulation of the subject.

Papers related to the subject:
1. Electroencephalographic Patterns in Chronic Pain: A Systematic Review of the Literature. E. Si. d. S. Pinheiro et al. 2016. PLoS One [[paper]](http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0149085)
2. Altered theta oscillations in resting EEG of fibromyalgia syndrome patients. Fallon et al. 2018. European journal of pain [[paper]](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/28758313/)
3. Altered Dynamic of EEG Oscillations in Fibromyalgia Patients at Rest. 2016. A. M. Gonzalez-Roldan et al. Pain medicine [[paper]](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26921889)

title: Playing with the Berlin Brain Connectivity Benchmark and Data Analysis Challenge (challenge from last year) to get some familiarity with source localization and connectivity in EEG data
body:
Added as an issue for book keeping

Source: https://brainhackghent.github.io/#projects

Leaders:
Iege Bassez, Kate Ergo and Davide Gheza

Aim:
All is described on this [website](http://bbci.de/supplementary/EEGconnectivity/BBCB.html). We would pick one of the simulated EEG datasets and try to answer following three questions:
1. Localization: In which two regions (brain octants) are the two alpha sources located?
2. Interaction: Does the data contain interaction (between the two sources) at all?
3. Directionality: If so, which estimated source octant contains the sending and which one the receiving source?

First we can go through the example processing pipeline (LCMV, ImCoh, and PSI) and then we can try to program our own pipeline.

When decided to participate, it’s recommended to read the [paper](http://bbci.de/supplementary/EEGconnectivity/BBCB_paper.pdf) of Haufe and Ewald and download the package including code and EEG/MEG head models (link on site, ~1.1 GB).

Skill(s) needed for taking part in the project:
Matlab scripting

title: Relating rest and task fMRI HRF parameters
body:
Added as an issue for book keeping

Source: https://brainhackghent.github.io/#projects

Leader:
Frederik Van de Steen

Aim:
In this project, we will build upon existing in house scripts to build an SPM12 pipeline for running first level analysis on the UGent HPC. The goal is to estimate all task fMRI data sets of the human connectome project (HCP). In addition, we will use recently developed technology to [retrieve the haemodynamic response function parameters of resting state fMRI](https://github.com/guorongwu/rsHRF) of the HCP. Finaly, we will relate the task-specific HRF parameters and resting state HRF parameters. In addition, BOLD signal of the vessels will be extracted for rest and task fMRI for comparison.

Skill(s) needed for taking part in the project:
Bash scripting

title: Building a container for reproducibility
body:
Added as an issue for book keeping

Source: https://brainhackghent.github.io/#projects

Leader:
Hannes Almgren

Aim:
In this project I would like to build a container with Docker to increase the reproducibility of results.
The container should include matlab, R, SPM, gramm-toolbox, igraph-library, and others.
The aim would be to put a fully functioning container on github.

Skill(s) needed for taking part in the project:
Bash scripting

title: Analyzing neurofeedback - EEG data
body:
Added as an issue for book keeping

Source: https://brainhackghent.github.io/#projects

Leader:
Wouter Devos

Provided data:
A set of EEG data from a neurofeedback training before and after X training sessions.

Aim:
1. To decide whether the training was/will be effective.
2. Maybe if there is still some time left: To reconstruct what "exactly" has changed in the brain structure/functioning as a result of the training.

Papers related to the subject:
1. [Potential of neurofeedback](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23623825)
2. [Assessment of effectiveness (1)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4911408/)
3. [Assessment of effectiveness (2)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5575615/)
